script.speaker: David
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm David.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And I'm Sarah. Happy to be here!

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, I’ve got a question that’s been nagging at me. What if I told you there’s something most people miss in the Creation story—something hidden in plain sight in Genesis 1 that points directly to Jesus Christ? Have you ever noticed a detail like that?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Oh, absolutely, David. I think I know where you’re going, and it’s one of my favorite insights. There’s a moment in the Creation account that’s so subtle, but it shifts everything when you see it. Let me build up to it—let’s start with the very first verse in Genesis 1:1, ‘In the beginning God created the heaven and the earth.’

script.speaker: David
script.text: Okay, I’m intrigued. That’s familiar to everyone, but what are we missing? How does this connect to Christ right from the start?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Here’s the first piece of the puzzle. When we read about the Creation in Moses 2:1, it says, ‘I am the Lord God Almighty, and Endless is my name; for I am without beginning of days or end of years.’ Now, who is speaking here? It’s Jesus Christ, the Creator under the direction of the Father. This sets the stage for understanding His role from the very beginning.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Wait, so you’re saying that when we read ‘God’ in these accounts, it’s often Christ Himself? That’s already shifting how I see this. But let’s look at it from different perspectives—how did ancient Israel understand this, compared to how we see it now through modern revelation?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Great question. Ancient Israel likely saw God as a singular, powerful Creator, often focusing on His majesty and authority over chaos, as described in Genesis 1:2 where the earth was ‘without form, and void.’ But through modern revelation, like in Moses 2 and Abraham 4, we get this added layer—Christ as the active Creator, working under the Father’s plan. It’s a clearer picture of the Godhead’s teamwork and Christ’s central role in our eternal story.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That’s fascinating. So, from Israel’s view, it’s about God’s power over creation, but from our view, it’s also about Christ’s personal involvement. Now, let’s dig deeper. Is there a pattern here that ties Christ to the Creation across different scriptures or dispensations?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Yes, and this is where it gets exciting. Notice this theme of light. In Genesis 1:3, God says, ‘Let there be light: and there was light.’ Now fast forward to John 8:12, where Jesus declares, ‘I am the light of the world.’ This isn’t just a metaphor—Christ is the source of both physical and spiritual light, from the Creation to His ministry.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I’m seeing it! So, the light on the first day of Creation is almost a preview of Christ as the spiritual light. Does this pattern show up anywhere else?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Absolutely. Look at Doctrine and Covenants 88:7-9, where it says, ‘This is the light of Christ. As also he is in the sun, and the light of the sun.’ The light of Christ permeates all creation—it’s a thread from Genesis to the Restoration. It shows His power to transform darkness into light in our lives, just as He did with the earth.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That’s remarkable. I never connected the literal light of Creation to the light of Christ in such a direct way. Now, let’s add some historical context. Is there anything from the ancient world that makes this even more vivid?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Definitely. In ancient Near Eastern cultures, light was often associated with divine presence and order overcoming chaos. When Genesis 1 describes light appearing on the first day, it would have signaled to ancient readers that God’s power was bringing structure to a formless world. Knowing this, we can see Christ’s role as light not just as a spiritual symbol, but as a cultural declaration of His divine authority over all things.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That’s a time-collapse moment for me—imagining ancient people hearing this story and feeling that same awe. So, going back to the mystery you hinted at earlier, what’s the hidden piece in Genesis 1 that points to Christ? I’m dying to know.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Here’s where it gets powerful. In Genesis 1:26, it says, ‘Let us make man in our image, after our likeness.’ That plural ‘us’ and ‘our’—many scholars see this as evidence of the Godhead, including Christ, collaborating in the Creation. Christ isn’t just executing the plan; He’s part of the divine council, shaping us to become like Him.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Wow, I’ve read that verse countless times and never caught the ‘us’ as a clue to Christ’s presence. That’s a profound connection. Are there other hidden links in these chapters that tie back to Him?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Oh, yes. Look at the Garden of Eden in Genesis 2:9, with the tree of life. Compare that to Revelation 22:2, where the tree of life is in the New Jerusalem, symbolizing eternal life through Christ. It’s as if the Creation story plants seeds of the Atonement and eternal life right from the start.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That’s incredible. So, the tree of life isn’t just a detail—it’s a symbol of Christ’s ultimate gift. How does this connect to the Plan of Salvation overall?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: It’s central. The Creation sets the stage for our mortal journey—being created in God’s image, as in Genesis 1:26-27, means we have divine potential. The tree of life represents the way back to Him through Christ’s Atonement. Every step of the Creation is purposeful, pointing to our eternal destiny.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I love how this ties everything together. Now, let’s bring this into our lives today. How can understanding Christ as the Creator and the light change the way we see ourselves or our challenges?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: It’s transformative. When life feels chaotic, like the earth ‘without form, and void’ in Genesis 1:2, we can remember that Christ brought light and order then, and He can do it for us now. Knowing we’re created in His image reminds us of our worth and potential, even on hard days.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That’s such a comforting thought. I’m inspired to look at my own life and see where I need His light to bring order. Sarah, as we wrap up, what’s one thing you’d invite our listeners to do based on what we’ve discovered?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I’d invite everyone to take a moment this week to read Genesis 1:26-27 and ponder what it means to be created in God’s image. Maybe go outside, look at His creations, and feel that connection to Christ as your Creator. Let that shape how you see yourself and others.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That’s a beautiful invitation. Thank you, Sarah, for uncovering these profound connections with us. I know I’ll never read the Creation story the same way again.
